text: Number 54, United States, Petitioner, versus Dorothy Anne Stapf and B. T. Ware, Executors.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
Is she -- is she then to like to take under will what was (Inaudible)?
She would take only her half of the community property and all of his property, his half of the community property plus his separate property would go to a trust for the children.
I think I understand.
She is entitled to one-half of all the community property less one-half of the debts.
That --
Of the community, yes.
And -- and --
She would have taken -- let me give you the figures.
As result of Texas law?
As result Texas law, that is correct.
(Inaudible) --
No, no.
That is -- that is half of the community property?
Well, she kept --
-- she -- under the will, she kept at 30 of the property--
Yes.
-- which is $85,000.
Right.
-- the difference between (Voice Overlap)
-- there's been a third and a half of the community property
Which is $26,000.
Well, what happened to the debts?
The debts really don't enter in to this part of the case.
But the purpose of the election I suppose is to give her a choice of one situation as more advantageous than the other.
Well, the election really amounts nothing more than offer made in the will, an offer that I will trade you $122,000 worth of separate my property --
(Voice Overlap) position that all elections, widow's elections are --
No, not an election, not an election that is an election between two alternative ways of receiving property by descent i.e. between dower and a statutory right, knew of dower.
And that's not permissible?
It's permissible to do but the consequence cannot be that the estate is entitled to marital deduction.

Mr. Chief Justice and members of the Court, I think it is a misnomer to characterize the will here as a gift of property upon a condition that Mrs. Stapf permits her property to pass through the trustees.
Mr. Sutton, she would've had that election whether or not the will had discussed her election which is a matter of state law and then --
No.
-- she has the statutory rights?
Under the state law, the husband or the wife, as far as that's concerned, can dispose of only his or her one-half of the community property by will.
Right.
But it is a recognized principle that by the marital deduction, a husband or wife, either as far as that goes, can dispose of both halves of the community with the consent of the surviving spouse.
Well, if she takes against the will if I understand you correctly --
If she takes --
-- all she gets is her half of this community property --
Correct, sir.
Which she -- which she would have whether or not there was a will --
That is right.
-- which is always her.
That is her, that's fully vested interest.
Right.
So, now when she elected under -- to take under the will, she made a gift of her property or of her fully vested portion of the community property to trustees for the benefit of their children.
We'll recess now Mr. Sutton.
